title: Eukaryotic Animal Cells - Nucleus & Ribosomes
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Structure and function of the nucleus and ribosomes in eukaryotic animal cells. Compares eukaryotic 80S ribosomes with prokaryotic 70S ribosomes.

engagementHook.title: The Cell's Control Centre
engagementHook.content: If the DNA from a single human cell were stretched out, it would be 2 metres long. Yet it fits inside a nucleus only 6 micrometres across—that's like packing 20km of thread into a backpack. How is this possible? And why does the cell need such complex packaging?

keyConcepts.definition: Double membrane surrounding the nucleus. Outer membrane continuous with ER. Contains nuclear pores for transport.
Protein complex in nuclear envelope regulating passage of molecules. Allows RNA out, proteins in.
Dense region inside nucleus where rRNA is synthesised and ribosomal subunits assembled. Not membrane-bound.
DNA + histone proteins. Exists as euchromatin (active, loose) or heterochromatin (inactive, condensed).
'Beads on a string'—DNA wrapped around histone octamer. Basic unit of DNA packaging.
Eukaryotic ribosome: 40S + 60S subunits. Found in cytoplasm and on rough ER. Larger than prokaryotic 70S.

misconceptions.misconception: The nucleus is the only place with DNA
misconceptions.correction: Mitochondria (and chloroplasts in plants) also contain DNA. Nuclear DNA is linear; mitochondrial DNA is circular like prokaryotes.

misconceptions.misconception: Chromosomes only exist during cell division
misconceptions.correction: DNA is always organised into chromosomes, but they're only VISIBLE as distinct X-shapes during mitosis. In interphase, chromatin is diffuse.
Both are ribosomes (protein synthesis machines). The numbers refer to Svedberg units (sedimentation rate), not just size. Both have large and small subunits.

contentSections.title: Nuclear Envelope Structure
contentSections.content: The nucleus is surrounded by a double membrane called the nuclear envelope. The outer membrane is continuous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Nuclear pores span both membranes, regulating transport between nucleus and cytoplasm. The nucleolus inside is the site of ribosome assembly.
keyPoints: Nucleolus has no membrane—it's a condensed region
contentSections.example: mRNA produced in nucleus must exit through pores to reach cytoplasmic ribosomes. Ribosomal proteins made in cytoplasm must enter through pores to reach nucleolus.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why does the nuclear envelope have pores instead of being a solid barrier?

contentSections.title: DNA Packaging Hierarchy
contentSections.content: Human cells contain 2 metres of DNA that must fit in a 6 µm nucleus. This is achieved through multiple levels of packaging: DNA double helix wraps around histone proteins forming nucleosomes ('beads on a string'). Nucleosomes coil into chromatin fibres, which further condense into chromosomes during cell division.
keyPoints: Histones are positively charged proteins (bind negatively charged DNA)
Nucleosome = 147 base pairs wrapped around histone octamer
contentSections.example: Euchromatin (loose) = active genes can be transcribed. Heterochromatin (tight) = genes silenced. X-chromosome inactivation in females creates Barr body (heterochromatin).
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why must DNA be able to uncoil from chromosomes back to accessible chromatin?

contentSections.title: Ribosome Comparison: 70S vs 80S

items: Found in: Animals, plants, fungi, protists

contentSections.note: Note: Eukaryotic mitochondria and chloroplasts have 70S ribosomes—evidence for endosymbiotic origin.
contentSections.example: Antibiotic selectivity: Tetracycline binds 30S subunit of bacterial ribosome but cannot bind eukaryotic 40S subunit (different shape).

multipleChoice.question: Which statement correctly describes the nuclear envelope?
multipleChoice.rationale: The nuclear envelope consists of inner and outer membranes (like two parallel bilayers). Nuclear pores span both and regulate transport. Outer membrane is continuous with ER, not Golgi.

multipleChoice.question: The nucleolus is responsible for:
multipleChoice.rationale: The nucleolus is where rRNA is transcribed and combined with ribosomal proteins to form 40S and 60S subunits. DNA storage is throughout nucleus; mRNA synthesis is transcription; pore regulation is by pore proteins.

multipleChoice.question: Eukaryotic ribosomes are 80S. This means they:
options: Sediment at 80 Svedberg units in centrifugation
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Sediment at 80 Svedberg units in centrifugation
multipleChoice.rationale: The 'S' stands for Svedberg units—a measure of sedimentation rate during ultracentrifugation. It reflects size AND shape, not just mass or diameter. 80S ribosomes are ~25-30nm, not 80nm.

shortAnswer.question: Explain how the structure of eukaryotic 80S ribosomes makes them resistant to antibiotics that target prokaryotic 70S ribosomes. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: 80S ribosomes have different subunit composition (40S + 60S) vs 70S (30S + 50S)
1 mark: Different molecular shape/size means antibiotics cannot bind effectively
1 mark: This is 'selective toxicity'—antibiotics exploit structural differences
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'human cells are stronger' rather than explaining structural differences in ribosomes

definitions: Nuclear envelope: Double membrane surrounding nucleus; outer membrane continuous with ER.
Nuclear pore: Protein complex regulating transport between nucleus and cytoplasm.
Nucleolus: Region where rRNA is synthesised and ribosomal subunits assembled.
Nucleosome: DNA wrapped around histone octamer ('beads on a string').
Chromatin: DNA + histone proteins (euchromatin = active; heterochromatin = condensed).
80S ribosome: Eukaryotic ribosome (40S + 60S subunits); larger than prokaryotic 70S.
keyPoints: DNA packaging: DNA → nucleosome → chromatin → chromosome
Nuclear pores allow mRNA out and proteins in
Nucleolus has no membrane; site of ribosome assembly
80S vs 70S ribosomes differ in subunit composition
diagrams: Labelled nuclear envelope showing pores and membranes

shortAnswer: Eukaryotic 80S ribosomes consist of 40S and 60S subunits, whereas prokaryotic 70S ribosomes have 30S and 50S subunits. The different sizes and shapes of these subunits mean that antibiotics like tetracycline, which bind to the 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, cannot bind effectively to the 40S subunit of eukaryotic ribosomes. This 'selective toxicity' allows antibiotics to kill bacteria without harming human cells.
